issues.description: The UML diagram in the problem statement declares the class as "Course" (lines 63-74) while the exercise text and both template and solution Java files consistently refer to the class as "Lecture". This mismatch of the class name in the UML can confuse students about which class they should implement and about the mapping between the UML and the Java files.
issues.suggested_fix: Update the UML in the problem statement to use the class name 'Lecture' instead of 'Course' so it matches the textual description, the template, and the solution. For example, change the UML header 'class Course {' to 'class Lecture {' and ensure any labels in the UML refer to 'Lecture'. This preserves the intended design while removing class-name confusion.

issues.description: The problem statement's UML uses the class name 'Course' (lines 63-74 of problem_statement.md) while the rest of the exercise (text, template and solution code) consistently refer to the entity as 'Lecture' (template: Lecture.java, solution: Lecture.java). This name divergence for the same conceptual entity (the lecture/course model and its attributes/methods) can confuse students when mapping the written requirements and UML to the provided starter code and the expected solution.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the class name consistent across artifacts. Update the UML in problem_statement.md to use 'class Lecture { ... }' instead of 'class Course { ... }' so it matches the textual description, the template Lecture.java and the solution Lecture.java. Alternatively, if 'Course' was intended, rename the template and solution classes (and references) to 'Course' — but preferrably align the UML to 'Lecture' to preserve the existing code and exercise wording.
